Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up the statement that West Virginia has the highest overdose rate per capita.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that West Virginia has the highest overdose rate per capita without considering other factors or alternative explanations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that West Virginia does have the highest overdose rate per capita, as supported by official government data and analysis from the Kaiser Family Foundation.
Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as an exaggeration since it states that West Virginia has the highest overdose rate per capita of any state in the nation, without providing context or comparison to other states.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim understates the overdose rate in West Virginia.
Falters at times: The claim does not appear to falter at times as it is supported by official data and analysis.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or factors that may contribute to the high overdose rate in West Virginia.
